headline: Recipe Of The Day: Trail Mix
image_caption(s): Easy Nachos With Fontina Queso + Candied Jalapeños
article: We're going to let you in on a little secret: you don't really need a recipe for trail mix. It's pretty much the simplest thing you could ever make in your kitchen. Trail mix is nothing more than a simple combination of nuts, dried fruit and/or chocolate. Yep, it's that easy. But if you're feeling a little trail mix shy, this recipe will send you confidently on your way to becoming a trail mix-making master. This recipe starts with an assortment of raw nuts and roasts them in the oven -- we recommend this for the freshest taste -- and then mixes them various dried fruits. Feel free to tweak to your liking, and add in anything you're missing. But whatever you do, don't waste your money on another store-bought trail mix ever again.Get the Fruit-and-Nut Trail Mix recipeWant to read more from HuffPost Taste? Follow us on Twitter, Facebook, Pinterest and Tumblr.Get more snack recipes!

headline: Jonathan Adler, Interior Designer, Loves Orange, Hates Mauve (PHOTOS)
short descr: ** Have something to say? Check out HuffPost Home on Twitter, Facebook, Pinterest, Tumblr and Instagram. Adler sat down with
image_caption(s): Happy Chic by Jonathan Adler Katie Duvet Cover Set & Accessories
article: Designer and potter Jonathan Adler is known for his funky designs and use of bright colors. But there is one hue he isn't touching anytime soon: mauve.Adler sat down with Refinery29 to discuss his line Happy Chic for JCPenney, and said he's absolutely avoiding the pale color. "Dude...the kids are rocking an '80s-comeback thing, but mauve is like the one thing I will never, ever embrace," he said.But he IS a big fan of orange. But that's obvious, if you look at his collection. Scroll through to see some of our favorites from "Happy Chic," and be sure to head over to Refinery29 for more information. Have something to say? headline: Bok Choy Recipes: A Taste Of China (PHOTOS)
short descr: One of our favorite Chinese cooking staples.
image_caption(s): Chinese Noodle Recipe with Chicken, Bok Choy & Hoisin Sauce
article: Bok choy may be relatively unseen in most American kitchens, but its tradition is long rooted in Chinese culture. A common feature of Asian-inspired recipes, bok choy is not only tasty but has a variety of important health benefits. Most commonly sautéed or braised, the many uses of bok choy are rarely fully taken advantage of -- mostly due to a general unfamiliarity with this veggie. So get to know this Asian staple and add a new favorite ingredient to your repertoire.Want to read more from HuffPost Taste? Follow us on Twitter, Facebook, Pinterest and Tumblr.

headline: Anmer Hall Almost Ready For Kate Middleton, Prince William & Prince George To Move In: REPORT
short descr: Do you have a home story idea or tip? Email us at homesubmissions@huffingtonpost.com. (PR pitches sent to this address will
image_caption(s): The Duke And Duchess Of Cambridge Leave The Lindo Wing With Their Newborn Son
article: It looks like Prince William, Kate and Prince George are finally getting ready to move into their presumed Anmer Hall country home. According to the Daily Mail, the Queen has reportedly paid the current tenant, James Everett, owner of timber company Norfolk Oak, to vacate the estate. His lease was set to expire in 2017, but hey, family is family. The news comes just months after learning that the Royal Couple have been planning major renovations for the Georgian property. Those plans supposedly include the addition of a garden room and pergola, along with a new driveway, a newly converted sitting room and a road for public visitors coming to and from St. Mary's Church.This will be the family's second home as they also have their Kensington Palace apartment, which will serve as their primary residence. Head over to the Daily Mail for more information. We just can't get enough of this family.Have something to say? Check out HuffPost Home on Twitter, Facebook, **Do you have a home story idea or tip? headline: Divorce Study Shows Infants' Attachment To Caregivers Affected By Joint Custody
short descr: Keep in touch! Check out HuffPost Divorce on Facebook and Twitter. The researchers looked at data from the Fragile Families
image_caption(s): Couples Who Share Housework Are More Likely To Divorce
article: Can joint custody inhibit an infant's attachment to his or her parents?According to a new study from researchers at the University of Virginia, infants who spent at least one night a week apart from their mothers formed less secure attachments to them, compared to babies who had fewer overnights away from home or stayed with their father only during the day.The researchers looked at data from the Fragile Families and Child Wellbeing Study, a national longitudinal study of about 5,000 children born in large U.S. cities from 1998 to 2000. The data consisted of interviews with the children's parents at the time of birth and at ages 1 and 3. Samantha Tornello, the study’s lead author, said that the attachments that babies form during their first year of life serve as the foundation for healthy attachments and relationships into adulthood. Because increasing numbers of parents are living apart from one another due to separation, divorce and children being born out of wedlock, kids are frequently raised in more than one home -- a custody arrangement that is likely determined by the legal system.“Judges often find themselves making decisions regarding custody without knowing what actually may be in the best interest of the child, based on psychology research,” Tornello said in a press release. “Our study raises the question, ‘Would babies be better off spending their overnights with a single caregiver, or at least less frequently in another home?’”According to Tornello, ideally the child would be in the care of the same consistent caregiver each night -- whether that's the father or the mother.“We would want a child to be attached to both parents, but in the case of separation a child should have at least one good secure attachment,” she said. “It’s about having constant caregivers that’s important.”This isn't the first study to find a link between parental divorce and childhood development. A recent study in the Journal of Consumer Affairs found that compulsive buying behavior in adulthood can be a result of parental divorce in childhood. And a July 2013 study by the University College London found that children of divorce have significantly higher levels of C-reactive protein -- a blood marker of inflammation that's associated with greater risk of heart disease and Type 2 diabetes.Click through the slideshow below to see more findings from recent divorce studies.Keep in touch! Check out HuffPost Divorce on Facebook and Twitter.

headline: Christina Ricci Engaged, Loves Saying 'Fiance'
short descr: Click through the slideshow below to see photos of Ricci over the years. Ricci also revealed to People that a friend designed
image_caption(s): NEW YORK, NY - JULY 28: Actress Christina Ricci attends 'The Smurfs 2' New York Blue Carpet Screening at Lighthouse International Theater on July 28, 2013 in New York City. (Photo by Monica Schipper/FilmMagic)
article: The best thing about being engaged, according to Christina Ricci, isn't planning the wedding, looking forward to the marriage or even admiring your engagement ring. It's calling your former boyfriend your "fiance.""People take you so much more seriously once you start throwing around that word," the actress told People magazine Sunday. "I can't wait for 'husband' because then I can really throw my weight around."Ricci also revealed to People that  a friend designed her wedding dress, which she helped to sketch. Ricci confirmed her engagement to her boyfriend of one year, James Heerdegen, in February. The pair met on the set of the ABC series "Pam Am," where Heerdegen worked as a dolly grip.Click through the slideshow below to see photos of Ricci over the years.Keep in touch! Check out HuffPost Weddings on Facebook, Twitter and Pinterest.
